title: Liverpool's Simon Mignolet explains why failing to hang onto lead at Manchester United has RAISED his title hopes
text:
Sport Liverpool's Simon Mignolet explains why failing to hang onto lead at Manchester United has RAISED his title hopes Conceding late equaliser hurt but we're stronger than 2014 side that was over-reliant on Luis Suarez says keeper Share Mignolet took plenty of positives from three points becoming one at Old Trafford (Photo: Liverpool FC via Getty) Share   Thank you for subscribing!   
Simon Mignolet says Liverpool proved they have the squad to push for this season's title — despite conceding a late equaliser at Manchester United. 
Mignolet made a string of fine saves at Old Trafford on Sunday, before eventually being beaten by a late Zlatan Ibrahimovic header as the home side salvaged a 1-1 draw. 
Taking one point instead of three meant the Reds missed out on going second outright behind leaders Chelsea. 
Jurgen Klopp’s side had to be content with moving up to third — level on points with Tottenham. 
But Mignolet believes Liverpool are now better equipped to push for the title than in 2014, when they were over-reliant on superstar striker Luis Suarez and ultimately came up short in their race with Manchester City. “Ask me is there any comparison to the team we had a few years ago with Suarez?” said Kop keeper Mignolet. “We were challenging for the title, but it was a totally different game and a totally different 11 people. 
“Then, we were a bit reliant on the individual ability of Suarez to make the difference and score goals. Now it’s more about the whole team, the way we create chances and defend as a unit. 
"We need everybody. That’s a good thing. It is always better to have a good unit than be reliant on one or two players. 
“People said when Phillipe Coutinho went out of the team [with a November injury that kept him sidelined until last Wednesday] it was going to be a big blow, but we dealt with it. Sadio Mane has gone to the Africa Cup of Nations, but we have more than enough players to help each other out.” Suarez was European football's joint-top scorer in 2013-14 with 31 league goals... (Photo: Getty) ...but couldn't quite drag Liverpool over the title-race line in first place (Photo: Getty) 
Mignolet claimed United were lucky to scrape a draw against a side who have yet to win in 2017 and now face a potentially tricky FA Cup third-round replay at fourth-tier Plymouth on Wednesday night. 
“You’re always disappointed when you concede a late goal,” he said. “They threw so many long balls at it and it’s always sore when they score. 
“They had a bit of luck. First, it comes off the post, then it comes off the bar. That’s the only way they could score. It’s a sour feeling. But we played well. 
"They threw everything they could at us. We still created chances on the counter-attack but unfortunately we couldn’t score the second goal, which would have killed the game. 
“We set up to try to win games. Against a team a team like United [on their own patch], that’s not always as easy as when you play at home. But we played our football. It’s a massive step if everyone is disappointed when you draw 1-1 at Old Trafford.” James Milner's first-half penalty had Liverpool on course to beat arch-rivals United... (Photo: PA) ...but with six minutes to go Zlatan Ibrahimovic got a fortunate equaliser... (Photo: Getty) ...to the despair of beaten keeper Mignolet (Photo: Man Utd via Getty) 
Mignolet has reclaimed his No.1 status from summer buy Loris Karius and suggested his time out of the first-team had enabled him to refocus and reproduce his best form. 
“I just focus on myself and when I have the chance to play, I just try to do my best,” said the Belgium international. “Of course I want to play every game. I always want to play, but it’s about making sure you stay ready. 
“At a club like Liverpool, it is normal there is going to be competition for every single place and there’s only one keeper who can play.” poll loading Who will finish higher this season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
